questions.question: Which graph shows direct proportionality between force and acceleration?
questions.explanation:
From F = ma (or a = F/m):
For constant m, a ∝ F → linear relationship.

Graph of a vs. F:
• Straight line
• Passes through origin (F=0 → a=0)
• Slope = 1/m

Experimental verification: This is how Newton's 2nd Law is tested with lab carts.

questions.question: A 0.5 kg ball is thrown and experiences 50 N of force during the throw. What's its acceleration?
questions.explanation:
a = F/m = 50 N / 0.5 kg = 100 m/s²

Extreme acceleration: 100 m/s² is about 10g (10 times gravity)!
Baseball reference: Pitcher's hand applies ~100 N force to baseball for ~0.01 seconds, giving ~40 m/s (90 mph) velocity.
Duration: Such high accelerations only last milliseconds during the throw.

questions.question: Why do heavy objects fall at the same rate as light objects (ignoring air resistance)?
options: Gravity force is proportional to mass
questions.explanation:
Gravity force (weight): F_gravity = mg
From F = ma: mg = ma → a = g

The m cancels! So acceleration = g for all objects.

Key insight: Heavier objects have more gravity force (mg), but also more inertia (m). These exactly balance, giving same a.
Experiment: Hammer and feather drop on Moon (no air) - fall together.

questions.question: Force needed to give 60kg mass 10m/s² upward acceleration (g=10m/s²) is
questions.explanation:
For upward acceleration:
F_net = ma (upward positive)
F_applied - mg = ma
F_applied = m(g + a) = 60(10 + 10) = 60 × 20 = 1200 N

Interpretation: Need to overcome weight (600N) PLUS provide acceleration force (600N).
Example: Rocket liftoff requires thrust > weight.

questions.question: A shopping cart accelerates at 0.5 m/s² when pushed with 30 N force. What is its mass?
questions.explanation:
From F = ma:
m = F/a = 30 N / 0.5 m/s² = 60 kg

Typical shopping cart: Empty cart ~20 kg, so this cart has about 40 kg of groceries.
Check: 60 kg is about 132 pounds - reasonable for a loaded cart.

questions.question: What is the net force on a 1 kg object in free fall on Earth?
questions.explanation:
In free fall (ignoring air resistance):
Only force = weight = mg = (1 kg)(9.8 m/s²) = 9.8 N

Net force = 9.8 N downward → acceleration = 9.8 m/s² downward.
With air: Eventually air resistance balances weight → net force → 0 → terminal velocity.

questions.question: If you want to double a car's acceleration without changing its mass, you must:
questions.explanation:
From a = F/m, with constant m:
To double a (a → 2a), you need F → 2F.

Net force must double.

Car example: Press gas pedal twice as hard (approximately double engine force, minus resistance).
Limitation: In reality, air resistance increases with speed, making constant acceleration impossible at high speeds.

questions.question: Which requires more force: accelerating 1 kg at 10 m/s² or 10 kg at 1 m/s²?
questions.explanation:
F₁ = (1 kg)(10 m/s²) = 10 N
F₂ = (10 kg)(1 m/s²) = 10 N

Both require 10 N of force.

Product ma: Both have ma = 10 kg·m/s² = 10 N.
Different effects: 1 kg would reach 10 m/s in 1 second, 10 kg would reach 1 m/s in 1 second.

questions.question: A rocket's acceleration increases during liftoff even though engine thrust is constant because:
questions.explanation:
From a = F_net/m
• Thrust (F) roughly constant
• Mass (m) decreases as fuel burns
• So a = F/m increases

Also: Weight (mg) decreases slightly as rocket rises (g decreases), but mass decrease is main factor.
Dramatic effect: Saturn V rocket: Initial mass 3,000 tons, final mass (after fuel) ~200 tons!

questions.question: The mathematical statement of Newton's 2nd Law is:
questions.explanation:
∑F = ma is the fundamental equation.

Where:
• ∑F = net force (vector sum of all forces)
• m = mass (scalar)
• a = acceleration (vector)

Key points:
1. Direction: a same direction as ∑F
2. Net force: Sum of ALL forces
3. Units: 1 N = 1 kg·m/s²

Most important law for calculating motion!

questions.question: Newton's Third Law of Motion states that:
options: For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction
Acceleration is directly proportional to net force
Objects at rest stay at rest
questions.explanation:
Key Concept: When one object exerts a force on a second object, the second object simultaneously exerts a force equal in magnitude and opposite in direction on the first object.

Simple Example: When you push on a wall, the wall pushes back on you with exactly the same amount of force.

Key Takeaway: Forces always come in pairs - you can't push something without it pushing back on you!

questions.question: When you push against a wall, the wall pushes back on you with:
questions.explanation:
Newton's 3rd Law in Action: Your hands push on the wall, and simultaneously the wall pushes back on your hands with equal force.

Why You Don't Move: Other forces (like friction between your feet and the floor) balance the wall's push.

Key Takeaway: The wall's push back is exactly equal to your push - no more, no less.

questions.question: A rocket burns 0.01kg of fuel each second and ejects it as a gas with velocity of 5000m/s. What force does the gas exert on the rocket?
questions.explanation:
Step 1: Understand what's happening
• Rocket pushes gas backward at high speed
• Gas pushes rocket forward (action-reaction)

Step 2: Calculate thrust
Thrust = (mass burned per second) × (exhaust speed)
Thrust = 0.01 kg/s × 5000 m/s = 50 N

Step 3: Apply 3rd Law
If gas pushes backward with 50N force, rocket pushes forward with 50N force (equal & opposite)

Key Takeaway: Rocket propulsion works by pushing gas backward → gas pushes rocket forward.

questions.question: A swimmer pushes water backward with her arms. What causes her to move forward?
questions.explanation:
Action-Reaction Pair:
• Action: Swimmer pushes water BACKWARD
• Reaction: Water pushes swimmer FORWARD

Everyday Examples:
• Rowing: Oars push water back → water pushes boat forward
• Walking: Foot pushes ground back → ground pushes you forward

Key Takeaway: To move something forward, you need to push something else backward.

questions.question: Two ice skaters push against each other. Skater A (50kg) pushes skater B (75kg). Which statement is true?
questions.explanation:
Newton's 3rd Law: The force between two objects is always equal for both.

What happens:
• Skater A pushes Skater B with force F
• Skater B pushes Skater A with force F (same amount!)

Why they move differently:
• Skater A (50kg): accelerates more (F=ma, smaller m → larger a)
• Skater B (75kg): accelerates less (larger m → smaller a)

Key Takeaway: Forces between two objects are always equal, but accelerations depend on mass.

questions.question: A book rests on a table. The force of the book on the table and the force of the table on the book are:
options: Equal and in the same direction
Unequal and in the same direction
questions.explanation:
Action-Reaction Pair:
• Action: Book pushes DOWN on table (its weight)
• Reaction: Table pushes UP on book (normal force)

Important Distinction:
These equal/opposite forces are NOT what keeps the book at rest!

Why book stays at rest (1st Law):
Downward weight = Upward normal force → Net force = 0 → No motion

Key Takeaway: Table pushes up exactly as hard as book pushes down.

questions.question: Why does a gun recoil when fired?
questions.explanation:
Action-Reaction Pair:
• Action: Gun pushes bullet FORWARD
• Reaction: Bullet pushes gun BACKWARD (recoil)

Why bullet moves faster:
• Bullet: Small mass → Large acceleration
• Gun: Large mass → Small acceleration (recoil)

Safety Note: Always hold guns firmly to control recoil!

Key Takeaway: Recoil is the bullet pushing back on the gun with equal force.

questions.question: A horse pulls a cart. According to Newton's 3rd Law, the cart pulls back on the horse with equal force. Why does the system move forward?
options: The horse pushes harder on the ground
The cart's force is actually smaller
The horse's muscles overcome the cart's pull
Net force on horse is forward due to ground reaction
questions.explanation:
Forces on Horse:
1. Cart pulls horse BACKWARD (equal to horse's pull on cart)
2. Ground pushes horse FORWARD (friction)

If ground push > cart pull → Horse accelerates forward

Forces on Cart:
1. Horse pulls cart FORWARD
2. Friction pulls cart BACKWARD

If horse pull > friction → Cart accelerates forward

Key Takeaway: The horse-cart forces are internal. Motion happens because ground pushes horse forward.

questions.question: When you jump off a small boat onto a dock, the boat moves backward because:
questions.explanation:
Action-Reaction Pair:
• Action: You push boat BACKWARD with your feet
• Reaction: Boat pushes you FORWARD toward dock

Why boat moves more:
• You: Jump toward dock (controlled motion)
• Boat: Lightweight → moves backward noticeably

Safety: This is why small boats can be unstable!

Key Takeaway: Pushing off something makes it move in the opposite direction.

questions.question: A balloon flies around the room when air escapes because:
questions.explanation:
Action-Reaction Pair:
• Action: Balloon pushes air OUT BACKWARD
• Reaction: Air pushes balloon FORWARD

Similar to: Rocket propulsion!

Fun Experiment: Blow up balloon, release it - it zooms around!

Key Takeaway: Pushing air backward makes the balloon move forward.

questions.question: Two people pull on opposite ends of a rope in a tug-of-war. Both pull with 500N force. What is the tension in the rope?
questions.explanation:
Understanding Tension:
• Person A pulls rope with 500N → rope pulls Person A with 500N
• Person B pulls rope with 500N → rope pulls Person B with 500N

Rope Experience:
Rope feels 500N at each end → tension throughout = 500N

If forces unequal:
Rope would accelerate toward stronger puller

Key Takeaway: Tension in rope equals the pulling force at either end when balanced.

questions.question: A jet engine develops thrust of 270N when exhaust velocity is 300m/s. Mass ejected per second is
questions.explanation:
Step 1: Recall thrust formula
Thrust = (mass ejected per second) × (exhaust speed)

Step 2: Rearrange formula
Mass per second = Thrust ÷ Exhaust speed

Step 3: Calculate
Mass per second = 270N ÷ 300m/s = 0.90 kg/s

Step 4: Apply 3rd Law
Engine pushes gas back at 270N → Gas pushes engine forward at 270N

Key Takeaway: Thrust depends on both how much mass you eject and how fast you eject it.

questions.question: When a hammer hits a nail, the nail goes into wood because:
options: Reaction force from nail on hammer
Action force from hammer on nail
questions.explanation:
Action-Reaction Pair:
• Action: Hammer exerts force on NAIL (drives it in)
• Reaction: Nail exerts force on HAMMER (stops it)

Why nail moves more:
• Nail: Small mass → Large acceleration into wood
• Hammer: Large mass → Small deceleration

What you feel: The reaction force in your hand!

Key Takeaway: Hammer pushes nail, nail pushes back equally on hammer.

questions.question: A person standing still on the ground exerts a force on Earth. Earth exerts:
questions.explanation:
Action-Reaction Pair:
• Action: Person pushes DOWN on Earth (weight)
• Reaction: Earth pushes UP on person (normal force)

Forces are EQUAL!

Why Earth doesn't move noticeably:
Earth's mass is HUGE (6×10²⁴ kg!) → Tiny acceleration

Fun Fact: You're technically moving Earth when you jump!

Key Takeaway: Earth pushes up on you exactly as hard as you push down on it.

questions.question: In a collision between a car and a truck, which experiences greater force?
questions.explanation:
Newton's 3rd Law: During impact:
• Force car exerts on truck = Force truck exerts on car

Why car gets more damaged:
• Car: Lighter → Larger acceleration → More deformation
• Truck: Heavier → Smaller acceleration → Less damage

Safety Lesson: This is why collisions with heavier vehicles are more dangerous!

Key Takeaway: Forces in collisions are always equal, but effects differ due to mass differences.

questions.question: A fish swims by pushing water backward with its fins. This works because:
questions.explanation:
Action-Reaction Pair:
• Action: Fish pushes water BACKWARD with fins
• Reaction: Water pushes fish FORWARD

All Swimming/Flying Works This Way:
• Birds: Push air down/back → Air pushes bird up/forward
• Rockets: Push exhaust down → Exhaust pushes rocket up

Key Takeaway: To move forward, push something backward.

questions.question: A rocket burns fuel at 10kg/s and ejects it at 5×10³m/s. The thrust is
questions.explanation:
Step 1: Write what's given
• Mass burned per second = 10 kg/s
• Exhaust speed = 5 × 10³ m/s = 5000 m/s

Step 2: Apply thrust formula
Thrust = (mass per second) × (exhaust speed)
Thrust = 10 kg/s × 5000 m/s = 50,000 N

Step 3: Write in scientific notation
50,000 N = 5.0 × 10⁴ N

Step 4: 3rd Law Application
Rocket pushes gas back with 50,000N → Gas pushes rocket forward with 50,000N

Key Takeaway: Thrust = (mass flow rate) × (exhaust velocity)

questions.question: When you walk forward, your foot pushes backward on the ground. The ground:
questions.explanation:
Action-Reaction Pair:
• Action: Foot pushes ground BACKWARD
• Reaction: Ground pushes foot FORWARD

Try This: Walk on ice (low friction) → Foot slips back!

Why Ice is Slippery:
Ground can't push forward effectively with low friction

Key Takeaway: Ground pushes you forward when you push it backward.

questions.question: A bird flies by pushing air downward with its wings. What keeps the bird up?
questions.explanation:
Action-Reaction Pair:
• Action: Wings push air DOWNWARD
• Reaction: Air pushes wings UPWARD (lift)

Forward Motion Too:
Wings also push air backward → Air pushes bird forward

Airplanes Work Same Way:
Wings deflect air downward → Air pushes plane upward

Key Takeaway: Pushing air down creates upward lift.

questions.question: Two magnets attract each other. Magnet A pulls on magnet B with force F. Magnet B pulls on magnet A with:
questions.explanation:
Newton's 3rd Law Applies to ALL Forces:
• Gravity
• Magnetic
• Electric
• Contact forces

Magnet Example:
• Magnet A attracts Magnet B with force F
• Magnet B attracts Magnet A with force F (equal!)

Works for Repulsion Too:
If magnets repel, forces are still equal

Key Takeaway: Magnetic forces between two objects are always equal.

questions.question: A person in a canoe throws a heavy backpack forward. The canoe moves:
questions.explanation:
Action-Reaction Pair:
• Action: Person throws backpack FORWARD
• Reaction: Backpack pushes person (and canoe) BACKWARD

Conservation of Momentum:
Initially: Everything at rest (total momentum = 0)
After: Backpack forward + Canoe backward = 0

Space Application:
Astronauts use this to move in space!

Key Takeaway: Throwing something forward pushes you backward.

questions.question: Which statement about action-reaction forces is FALSE?
questions.explanation:
Why They DON'T Cancel:
Forces cancel only when acting on the SAME object

Example - Book on Table:
• Book pushes table → affects TABLE
• Table pushes book → affects BOOK
Different objects → Don't cancel!

Other Statements are TRUE:
1. Act on different objects ✓
2. Equal in magnitude ✓
3. Opposite direction ✓

Key Takeaway: Action-reaction forces act on different objects, so they don't cancel.

questions.question: A firefighter points a fire hose horizontally. The water shoots out with great force, and the firefighter must hold tight because:
questions.explanation:
Action-Reaction Pair:
• Action: Hose pushes water FORWARD
• Reaction: Water pushes hose (and firefighter) BACKWARD

Everyday Example:
Garden hose kicks back when turned on full force!

Safety: Firefighters brace themselves against this backward push

Key Takeaway: Pushing water forward creates backward reaction force.

questions.question: Earth's gravity pulls on the Moon. The Moon's gravity pulls on Earth:
questions.explanation:
Newton's 3rd Law Applies to Gravity:
• Action: Earth attracts Moon with force F
• Reaction: Moon attracts Earth with force F

Why Moon orbits Earth:
• Moon: Smaller mass → Larger acceleration → Orbits Earth
• Earth: Huge mass → Tiny acceleration → Slight wobble

Ocean Tides:
Moon's gravity causes tides on Earth!

Key Takeaway: Gravitational forces between two objects are always equal.

questions.question: Which demonstrates Newton's Third Law? I. Jet aircraft II. Rocket propulsion III. Gun recoil IV. Walking
questions.explanation:
ALL FOUR Demonstrate 3rd Law:

I. Jet Aircraft:
• Engine pushes exhaust BACKWARD
• Exhaust pushes aircraft FORWARD

II. Rocket Propulsion:
• Rocket pushes exhaust DOWN
• Exhaust pushes rocket UP

III. Gun Recoil:
• Gun pushes bullet FORWARD
• Bullet pushes gun BACKWARD

IV. Walking:
• Foot pushes ground BACKWARD
• Ground pushes foot FORWARD

Key Takeaway: Many everyday actions demonstrate action-reaction pairs!

questions.question: When a balloon is rubbed and sticks to a wall, the balloon pulls on the wall and the wall pulls on the balloon. These forces are:
questions.explanation:
3rd Law Applies to Electric Forces Too:
• Action: Balloon attracts wall with electric force F
• Reaction: Wall attracts balloon with force F

Why balloon moves more:
• Balloon: Light → Moves toward wall
• Wall: Heavy → Barely moves

Try This: Rub balloon on hair, stick to wall!

Key Takeaway: Electric forces between objects are also equal.

questions.question: A person pushes a stalled car. The car doesn't move because:
questions.explanation:
Two Different Concepts:

1. 3rd Law (Action-Reaction):
• Person pushes car forward
• Car pushes person backward
• These act on DIFFERENT objects

2. Why Car Doesn't Move (1st Law):
• Person pushes car forward (say 200N)
• Static friction pushes car backward (200N if not moving)
• Net force on car = 0 → Car stays at rest

Key Takeaway: Action-reaction forces don't cancel because they act on different objects.

questions.question: A squid moves by taking water into its body and expelling it rapidly. This works due to:
questions.explanation:
Action-Reaction Pair:
• Action: Squid pushes water BACKWARD (squirts it out)
• Reaction: Water pushes squid FORWARD

Nature's Jet Propulsion:
• Squids
• Octopuses
• Jellyfish

Speed: Some squids reach 25 mph this way!

Key Takeaway: Squid jet propulsion = underwater rocket science!

questions.question: In a perfectly elastic collision between two identical balls, ball A hits stationary ball B. After collision:
options: A stops, B moves with A's original speed
A bounces back, B moves forward
questions.explanation:
For Identical Masses:
• Ball A transfers ALL momentum to Ball B
• Ball A STOPS
• Ball B moves with A's original speed

3rd Law During Collision:
• A pushes B forward → B pushes A backward
• Forces equal → A slows to stop, B speeds to A's speed

Try This: Newton's cradle demonstrates this!

Key Takeaway: In elastic collisions of equal masses, first ball stops, second continues.

questions.question: A 5.0kg ball hits a wall at 2m/s and rebounds. The impulse on the wall is
questions.explanation:
Step 1: Find ball's momentum change
Initial momentum = 5kg × 2m/s = 10 kg·m/s (toward wall)
Final momentum = 5kg × (-2m/s) = -10 kg·m/s (away from wall)
Change = -10 - 10 = -20 kg·m/s

Step 2: Impulse on ball = -20 kg·m/s

Step 3: Apply 3rd Law
• Wall exerts -20 kg·m/s impulse on ball
• Ball exerts +20 kg·m/s impulse on wall

Step 4: Wall doesn't move much
Wall's mass huge → Very small velocity change

Key Takeaway: Impulse on wall equals ball's momentum change.

questions.question: A machine gun with a mass of 5kg fires a 50g bullet at a speed of 100m/s. The recoil speed of the machine gun is
questions.explanation:
Conservation of momentum:
Total momentum before = 0
Total momentum after = 0
0 = (0.05 × 100) + (5 × v)
0 = 5 + 5v
5v = -5
v = -1 m/s

Key Takeaway: Gun recoils at 1 m/s opposite to bullet direction.

questions.question: A 0.1kg arrow moving at 20 m/s hits and sticks into a 0.9kg stationary target. Their combined velocity is
questions.explanation:
Conservation of momentum:
(0.1 × 20) + 0 = (0.1 + 0.9) × v
2 = 1.0 × v
v = 2 m/s

Key Takeaway: Combined velocity = initial momentum ÷ total mass = 2 m/s.

questions.question: Two ice skaters push off from each other. Skater A (60 kg) pushes Skater B (40 kg). If Skater B moves at 3 m/s, Skater A's speed is
questions.explanation:
Conservation of momentum:
0 = (60 × v) + (40 × 3)
0 = 60v + 120
60v = -120
v = -2 m/s

Key Takeaway: Skater A moves at 2 m/s opposite to Skater B.

questions.question: A 1000 kg car moving east at 15 m/s collides with a 1500 kg truck moving west at 5 m/s. They stick together. Final velocity is
questions.explanation:
Conservation of momentum (east = +):
(1000 × 15) + (1500 × -5) = (1000 + 1500) × v
15000 - 7500 = 2500v
7500 = 2500v
v = 3 m/s (+ = east)

Key Takeaway: Final velocity is 3 m/s east.

questions.question: A 2 kg object at rest explodes into two equal pieces. One piece moves north at 6 m/s. The other piece's velocity is
questions.explanation:
Conservation of momentum:
Each piece mass = 1 kg
0 = (1 × 6 north) + (1 × v)
v = -6 m/s north = 6 m/s south

Key Takeaway: Equal pieces from explosion move in opposite directions at equal speeds.

questions.question: A gun of mass 2.0kg fires a 0.016kg bullet east at 150m/s. The gun's recoil velocity is
questions.explanation:
Conservation of momentum:
0 = (0.016 × 150) + (2.0 × v)
0 = 2.4 + 2.0v
2.0v = -2.4
v = -1.2 m/s (west)

Key Takeaway: Gun recoils at 1.2 m/s west.

questions.question: A 5 kg cart moving at 4 m/s collides with a stationary 10 kg cart. They stick together. Final speed is
questions.explanation:
Conservation of momentum:
(5 × 4) + 0 = (5 + 10) × v
20 = 15v
v = 20/15 = 1.33 m/s

Key Takeaway: Final speed = 1.33 m/s.

questions.question: A 3 kg object at rest explodes. One piece (1 kg) flies north at 6 m/s. The other piece's velocity is
questions.explanation:
Conservation of momentum:
Other piece mass = 2 kg
0 = (1 × 6 north) + (2 × v)
2v = -6
v = -3 m/s north = 3 m/s south

Key Takeaway: 2 kg piece moves south at 3 m/s.

questions.question: Two identical cars (1000 kg each) collide head-on at 10 m/s each and stick. Final velocity is
questions.explanation:
Conservation of momentum (right = +):
(1000 × 10) + (1000 × -10) = 2000 × v
10000 - 10000 = 2000v
0 = 2000v
v = 0 m/s

Key Takeaway: Cars come to complete rest.

questions.question: A 0.05 kg bullet embeds in a 0.95 kg block at rest. Combined they move at 10 m/s. Bullet's initial speed was
questions.explanation:
Conservation of momentum:
(0.05 × v) + 0 = (0.05 + 0.95) × 10
0.05v = 10
v = 200 m/s

Key Takeaway: Bullet was moving at 200 m/s.

questions.question: A 60 kg person jumps off a 1 kg skateboard at rest. Person jumps forward at 2 m/s. Skateboard's speed is
questions.explanation:
Conservation of momentum:
0 = (60 × 2) + (1 × v)
0 = 120 + v
v = -120 m/s (backward)

Key Takeaway: Skateboard recoils at 120 m/s backward.

questions.question: A 0.2 kg ball at 5 m/s hits a 0.3 kg ball at rest. First ball stops. Second ball's velocity is
questions.explanation:
Conservation of momentum:
(0.2 × 5) + 0 = 0 + (0.3 × v)
1.0 = 0.3v
v = 1.0/0.3 = 3.33 m/s

Key Takeaway: Second ball moves at 3.33 m/s.

questions.question: 4 kg at 6 m/s collides with 8 kg at 2 m/s in same direction. They stick. Final speed is
questions.explanation:
Conservation of momentum:
(4 × 6) + (8 × 2) = (4 + 8) × v
24 + 16 = 12v
40 = 12v
v = 40/12 = 3.33 m/s

Key Takeaway: Final speed is 3.33 m/s.

questions.question: 900 kg rocket ejects 100 kg fuel at 200 m/s backward. Rocket's forward speed is
questions.explanation:
Conservation of momentum:
0 = (100 × -200) + (900 × v)
0 = -20000 + 900v
900v = 20000
v = 20000/900 = 22.22 m/s

Key Takeaway: Rocket moves forward at 22.2 m/s.

questions.question: Mass M at rest splits into m and M-m. If piece m has velocity v, piece M-m has velocity
questions.explanation:
Conservation of momentum:
0 = mv + (M-m)V
(M-m)V = -mv
V = -mv/(M-m)

Key Takeaway: Other piece has velocity mv/(M-m) opposite direction.

questions.question: 12 kg at 4.2 m/s collides with 18 kg at rest. They stick. Common velocity is
questions.explanation:
Conservation of momentum:
(12 × 4.2) + 0 = (12 + 18) × v
50.4 = 30v
v = 50.4/30 = 1.68 ≈ 1.7 m/s

Key Takeaway: Common velocity is 1.7 m/s.

questions.question: 100 g ball at 10 m/s hits 300 g ball at 5 m/s opposite direction. They stick. Final velocity is
questions.explanation:
Conservation of momentum (lighter's direction = +):
0.1×10 + 0.3×(-5) = 0.4×v
1.0 - 1.5 = 0.4v
-0.5 = 0.4v
v = -1.25 m/s (heavier's direction)

Key Takeaway: Final velocity 1.25 m/s in heavier ball's direction.

questions.question: 2 kg at 3 m/s catches 1 kg at 1 m/s same direction. They stick. Final speed is
questions.explanation:
Conservation of momentum:
(2×3) + (1×1) = (2+1)×v
6 + 1 = 3v
7 = 3v
v = 7/3 = 2.33 ≈ 2.3 m/s

Key Takeaway: Final speed is 2.3 m/s.

questions.question: 0.5 kg ball east at 4 m/s collides with 0.5 kg ball north at 3 m/s. They stick. Final speed is
questions.explanation:
Conservation of momentum:
Momentum vectors: east = 2 kg·m/s, north = 1.5 kg·m/s
Resultant = √(2² + 1.5²) = √(4+2.25) = √6.25 = 2.5 kg·m/s
Mass = 1.0 kg, v = 2.5/1.0 = 2.5 m/s

Key Takeaway: Final speed is 2.5 m/s at angle northeast.

questions.question: 10 kg cannonball fired from 500 kg cannon. Cannon recoils at 2 m/s. Cannonball speed is
questions.explanation:
Conservation of momentum:
0 = (10×v) + (500×(-2))
0 = 10v - 1000
10v = 1000
v = 100 m/s

Key Takeaway: Cannonball speed is 100 m/s.

questions.question: 0.1 kg arrow at 15 m/s embeds in 0.4 kg block at rest. Their common velocity is
questions.explanation:
Conservation of momentum:
(0.1×15) + 0 = (0.1+0.4)×v
1.5 = 0.5v
v = 3 m/s

Key Takeaway: Common velocity is 3 m/s.

questions.question: Two 20,000 kg train cars at 5 m/s couple with third identical stationary car. Final speed is
questions.explanation:
Conservation of momentum:
Initial: 40,000 kg at 5 m/s = 200,000 kg·m/s
Final: 60,000 kg × v
200,000 = 60,000v
v = 200,000/60,000 = 3.33 m/s

Key Takeaway: Final speed is 3.3 m/s.

questions.question: 5 kg object at 8 m/s explodes into two equal pieces. One moves forward at 12 m/s. Other's velocity is
questions.explanation:
Conservation of momentum:
Each piece = 2.5 kg
5×8 = (2.5×12) + (2.5×v)
40 = 30 + 2.5v
2.5v = 10
v = 4 m/s forward

Key Takeaway: Other piece moves 4 m/s forward.

questions.question: 50 kg person running at 4 m/s jumps onto 10 kg cart at rest. Combined speed is
questions.explanation:
Conservation of momentum:
(50×4) + 0 = (50+10)×v
200 = 60v
v = 200/60 = 3.33 m/s

Key Takeaway: Combined speed is 3.3 m/s.

questions.question: 0.05 kg bullet at 200 m/s embeds in 0.95 kg block. Their combined velocity is
questions.explanation:
Conservation of momentum:
(0.05×200) + 0 = (0.05+0.95)×v
10 = 1.0×v
v = 10 m/s

Key Takeaway: Combined velocity is 10 m/s.

questions.question: 2 kg ball at 6 m/s hits 4 kg ball at rest elastically. 2 kg ball's final speed is
questions.explanation:
Elastic collision formula:
v₁' = [(m₁-m₂)/(m₁+m₂)]×v₁
v₁' = [(2-4)/(2+4)]×6
v₁' = [-2/6]×6 = -2 m/s

Key Takeaway: 2 kg ball rebounds at 2 m/s backward.

questions.question: Three identical balls in line. First hits second, second hits third. All elastic. Third ball's speed is
questions.explanation:
Momentum transfer in elastic collisions:
First stops, second moves at v
Second stops, third moves at v

Key Takeaway: Third ball moves at original speed v.

questions.question: 1000 kg car at 20 m/s rear-ends 1500 kg truck at 10 m/s same direction. They couple. Final speed is
questions.explanation:
Conservation of momentum:
(1000×20) + (1500×10) = 2500×v
20,000 + 15,000 = 2500v
35,000 = 2500v
v = 14 m/s

Key Takeaway: Final speed is 14 m/s.

questions.question: 2 kg object at 10 m/s breaks into 0.5 kg piece at 20 m/s and 1.5 kg piece. 1.5 kg piece's speed is
questions.explanation:
Conservation of momentum:
2×10 = (0.5×20) + (1.5×v)
20 = 10 + 1.5v
1.5v = 10
v = 6.67 m/s forward
Wait, 6.67 not in options.
For v=0: total = 10, need 20
For v=5: total = 10+7.5=17.5, need 20
For v=7.5: total = 10+11.25=21.25, need 20

Actually 6.67 m/s is correct but not in options.

questions.question: 2 kg object at 10 m/s breaks into 0.5 kg piece at 30 m/s and 1.5 kg piece. 1.5 kg piece's speed is
questions.explanation:
Conservation of momentum:
2×10 = (0.5×30) + (1.5×v)
20 = 15 + 1.5v
1.5v = 5
v = 5/1.5 = 3.33 m/s forward

Key Takeaway: 1.5 kg piece moves 3.33 m/s forward.

questions.question: Two identical objects approach each other at equal speeds v and stick together. Their final velocity is
questions.explanation:
Conservation of momentum:
Let right = +, left = -
mv + m(-v) = (2m)×v_final
mv - mv = 2m×v_final
0 = 2m×v_final
v_final = 0

Key Takeaway: They come to complete rest.

questions.question: The force required to make an object of mass m, travelling with velocity v, turn in a circle of radius r is
questions.explanation:
Centripetal Force Formula:
F = mv²/r

What it means:
• This force ALWAYS points toward the center of the circle
• It keeps the object moving in a circular path
• Without this force, the object would fly off in a straight line

Key Takeaway: Centripetal force = mv²/r, directed toward the center.

questions.question: The force holding the moon in its orbit around the earth is
questions.explanation:
Moon's Orbit:
• Earth's gravity pulls moon toward Earth
• This gravitational force acts as the CENTRIPETAL force
• It keeps the moon moving in a circular(ish) orbit

Common misconception: There is NO "centrifugal force" pushing outward

Key Takeaway: Gravity provides the centripetal force for orbital motion.

questions.question: A particle moves in a circular orbit of radius 0.02m at 0.88m/s. Its frequency is
questions.explanation:
Step 1: Find angular velocity
ω = v/r = 0.88/0.02 = 44 rad/s

Step 2: Convert to frequency
f = ω/(2π) = 44/(2×3.14) = 44/6.28 ≈ 7.0 Hz

Step 3: Check:
7 Hz means 7 complete circles per second

Key Takeaway: Frequency f = v/(2πr). Higher speed or smaller radius means higher frequency.

questions.question: If a whirling ball's string breaks, the ball moves
questions.explanation:
Newton's 1st Law:
• While whirling: String provides centripetal force inward
• When string breaks: No more inward force
• Ball continues in straight line tangent to circle

Example: Mud flying off a spinning tire goes tangent

Key Takeaway: Without centripetal force, objects move tangent to their circular path.

questions.question: Uniform circular motion has acceleration that is
options: Varying in both magnitude and direction
questions.explanation:
Uniform Circular Motion:
• Speed is constant
• Direction constantly changes
• Acceleration magnitude: a = v²/r (constant)
• Acceleration direction: Always toward center (constantly changing)

Visualize: Imagine running around a track at constant speed - you're always turning inward

Key Takeaway: In uniform circular motion, acceleration has constant magnitude but changing direction.

questions.question: In uniform circular motion:
options: Both energy and momentum are constant
questions.explanation:
Energy: KE = ½mv², v constant → KE constant

Momentum: p = mv, v constant magnitude but changing direction → p varies

Why momentum changes: Even though speed is same, direction changes, and momentum is a vector (needs direction)

Key Takeaway: Kinetic energy constant, momentum direction changes constantly.

questions.question: A 10g mass rotates at 100 rad/s on a 0.2m blade. Centripetal force is
questions.explanation:
Step 1: Convert units
m = 10 g = 0.01 kg
r = 0.2 m
ω = 100 rad/s

Step 2: Apply formula
F = mrω² = 0.01 × 0.2 × (100)²
F = 0.01 × 0.2 × 10000 = 20 N

Step 3: Check magnitude
20 N can lift about 2 kg - reasonable for high-speed rotation

Key Takeaway: F = mrω². High angular velocity creates large forces even with small mass.

questions.question: A 1500kg car takes a 50m radius curve at 40m/s. Centripetal force is
questions.explanation:
Step 1: Identify values
m = 1500 kg
v = 40 m/s (144 km/h)
r = 50 m

Step 2: Calculate force
F = mv²/r = 1500 × (40)² / 50
F = 1500 × 1600 / 50 = 2,400,000 / 50 = 48,000 N

Step 3: Write in scientific notation
48,000 N = 4.8 × 10⁴ N

Key Takeaway: F = mv²/r. Fast cars on tight curves need large centripetal forces.

questions.question: A 5kg mass moves in a circle. If centripetal force is tripled, new speed is
questions.explanation:
Relationship: F ∝ v² (for constant m and r)

Step 1: Set up proportion
F₂/F₁ = (v₂/v₁)²
3 = (v₂/v₁)²

Step 2: Solve for ratio
v₂/v₁ = √3 ≈ 1.73

Step 3: Interpretation
Tripling force increases speed by factor √3 ≈ 1.73

Key Takeaway: F ∝ v², so to triple force, speed increases by √3.

questions.question: A 1.2m diameter wheel rotates at 1 rev/s. A point on the rim has speed
questions.explanation:
Step 1: Find circumference
Diameter = 1.2 m → Radius = 0.6 m
Circumference = 2πr = 2 × 3.14 × 0.6 = 3.77 m

Step 2: Calculate speed
1 rev/s means travels circumference in 1 second
v = circumference/time = 3.77 m/s ≈ 3.8 m/s

Key Takeaway: v = 2πrf, where f is frequency in rev/s.

questions.question: A 2kg object moves at 10m/s in 4m radius circle. Centripetal force is
questions.explanation:
Step 1: Apply formula
F = mv²/r = 2 × (10)² / 4
F = 2 × 100 / 4 = 200 / 4 = 50 N

Step 2: Check reasonableness
50 N can lift about 5 kg - reasonable for this motion

Key Takeaway: F = mv²/r. Doubling speed quadruples force (if radius same).

questions.question: An object moves in 0.5m radius circle at 1m/s. Its angular velocity is
questions.explanation:
Step 1: Use relationship
v = rω → ω = v/r

Step 2: Calculate
ω = 1 / 0.5 = 2 rad/s

Step 3: Interpretation
2 rad/s means it rotates through 2 radians each second
2 rad ≈ 114° per second

Key Takeaway: ω = v/r. For same speed, smaller radius means higher angular velocity.

questions.question: A 100N body moves at 5m/s in 5m radius circle. Centripetal force is
questions.explanation:
Step 1: Find mass
Weight = mg = 100 N
Assuming g = 10 m/s²
m = weight/g = 100/10 = 10 kg

Step 2: Calculate centripetal force
F = mv²/r = 10 × (5)² / 5
F = 10 × 25 / 5 = 250 / 5 = 50 N

Key Takeaway: First find mass from weight, then use F = mv²/r.

questions.question: A gramophone record reaches 4π rad/s in 5s. Angular acceleration is
questions.explanation:
Step 1: Use angular acceleration formula
α = Δω/Δt

Step 2: Calculate
α = (4π - 0) / 5 = 4π/5 = 0.8π rad/s²

Step 3: Interpretation
0.8π ≈ 2.51 rad/s²
Each second, angular speed increases by 2.51 rad/s

Key Takeaway: α = (final ω - initial ω)/time. Same form as linear acceleration a = Δv/Δt.

questions.question: For a ball swinging in a vertical circle, maximum speed occurs
questions.explanation:
Energy Conservation:
• At top: Maximum height → Maximum potential energy
• At bottom: Minimum height → Maximum kinetic energy

Gravity's effect:
• From top to bottom: Gravity speeds up ball
• From bottom to top: Gravity slows down ball

Key Takeaway: In vertical circular motion, speed is maximum at lowest point due to gravity.

questions.question: A wheel makes 90 revolutions in 25s. Its frequency is
questions.explanation:
Step 1: Frequency definition
f = number of revolutions / time

Step 2: Calculate
f = 90 rev / 25 s = 3.6 Hz

Step 3: Interpretation
3.6 Hz means 3.6 complete circles per second

Key Takeaway: Frequency f = (number of revolutions)/time. Higher frequency means faster rotation.

questions.question: Which motion is NOT circular? I. Heartbeat II. Vertical spring III. Wheel rotation
questions.explanation:
Analyze each:

I. Heartbeat: Back-and-forth motion → Simple Harmonic Motion (SHM)

II. Vertical spring: Up-and-down oscillation → SHM

III. Wheel rotation: Continuous circular path → Circular motion

Key Takeaway: Circular motion requires continuous circular path. Back-and-forth motions are SHM, not circular.

questions.question: A particle performs 30 oscillations in 6s. Its angular velocity is
questions.explanation:
Step 1: Find frequency
f = oscillations/time = 30/6 = 5 Hz

Step 2: Convert to angular velocity
ω = 2πf = 2π × 5 = 10π rad/s

Step 3: Check:
10π ≈ 31.4 rad/s
That's about 5 complete circles per second

Key Takeaway: ω = 2πf. Frequency of 5 Hz gives angular velocity of 10π rad/s.

questions.question: A stone flies off when its string breaks because
questions.explanation:
Before break: String tension provides centripetal force inward

After break: No centripetal force → No force to change direction

Result: Stone moves tangent (Newton's 1st Law: objects in motion stay in motion)

Key Takeaway: Removing centripetal force causes object to move tangent to the circle.

questions.question: For a body moving with constant speed in a circular track:
questions.explanation:
Analyze each option:

A: Velocity: Direction changes → NOT constant

B: Work: Centripetal force ⊥ to motion → Work = F·d·cos90° = 0 ✓

C: Acceleration: Points INWARD (centripetal)

D: Momentum: Direction changes → NOT constant

Key Takeaway: Centripetal force does no work because it's always perpendicular to motion.

questions.question: The centripetal acceleration of an object moving in a circle depends on
questions.explanation:
Centripetal acceleration formula:
a = v²/r

What it depends on:
• v (speed) - squared relationship
• r (radius) - inverse relationship
• NOT mass!

Example: Car on curve: Acceleration depends on speed and curve tightness, not car's mass

Key Takeaway: Centripetal acceleration a = v²/r depends only on speed and radius, not mass.

questions.question: A car rounds a curve without skidding. The force preventing skidding is
questions.explanation:
On a flat road:
• Friction between tires and road provides centripetal force
• This friction force points toward center of curve

If friction is insufficient: Car skids outward

Banked curves: Normal force also helps provide centripetal force

Key Takeaway: Friction provides centripetal force for cars turning on flat roads.

questions.question: If radius is doubled while speed stays same, centripetal force becomes
questions.explanation:
Relationship: F ∝ 1/r (for constant m and v)

Step 1: Set up proportion
F₂/F₁ = r₁/r₂
F₂/F₁ = 1/2

Step 2: Interpretation
Doubling radius halves the centripetal force

Example: Same speed on wider curve needs less turning force

Key Takeaway: F ∝ 1/r. Wider curves require less centripetal force for same speed.

questions.question: The period of circular motion is the time for
questions.explanation:
Period (T) definition:
Time for one complete cycle/revolution

Relationships:
• T = 1/f (f = frequency)
• T = 2π/ω (ω = angular velocity)
• T = circumference/speed = 2πr/v

Example: If period = 2 seconds, object completes one circle every 2 seconds

Key Takeaway: Period = time for one complete revolution.

questions.question: For satellites in circular orbits, centripetal force is provided by
questions.explanation:
Satellite motion:
• Gravity pulls satellite toward Earth
• This gravitational force acts as centripetal force
• Keeps satellite in circular orbit

Important: Once in orbit, engines are OFF (except for adjustments)

Key Takeaway: Gravity provides the centripetal force for satellites in orbit.

questions.question: In a washing machine spin cycle, water is removed because
questions.explanation:
Physics of spin cycle:
• Clothes forced into circular motion by drum
• Water droplets have little adhesion to clothes
• Water can't get centripetal force to follow curve
• Water continues tangent (through holes in drum)

Key Takeaway: Water leaves because it can't get enough centripetal force to follow circular path.

questions.question: Angular velocity measures
questions.explanation:
Angular velocity (ω):
• Rate of change of angular position
• Units: rad/s or °/s
• ω = Δθ/Δt

Comparison:
• Linear velocity: How fast position changes (m/s)
• Angular velocity: How fast angle changes (rad/s)

Key Takeaway: Angular velocity = rate of change of angle (how fast something rotates).

questions.question: A 0.5 kg ball on 1m string makes 2 rev/s. Tension in string is
questions.explanation:
Step 1: Find angular velocity
f = 2 rev/s
ω = 2πf = 2π × 2 = 4π rad/s

Step 2: Calculate tension (centripetal force)
F = mrω² = 0.5 × 1 × (4π)²
F = 0.5 × 1 × 16π² = 8π² N

Step 3: Approximate value
8π² ≈ 8 × 9.87 = 79 N (can lift about 8 kg)

Key Takeaway: Tension provides centripetal force: T = mrω².

questions.question: For safe turning on a curve, a car should
questions.explanation:
Physics of turning:
• Centripetal force needed: F = mv²/r
• Friction provides this force
• Maximum friction force is limited

If speed too high:
Required F > maximum friction → Car skids

Safety rule: Slow down before curves!

Key Takeaway: Slower speeds require less centripetal force, reducing skid risk.

questions.question: Planets orbit the sun due to
questions.explanation:
Solar system orbits:
• Sun's gravity pulls planets toward sun
• This gravitational force is CENTRIPETAL force
• Keeps planets in (approximately) circular orbits

Kepler's laws: Describe these orbital motions

Key Takeaway: Sun's gravity provides centripetal force for planetary orbits.

questions.question: If a pendulum's length increases by 4×, its period increases by
questions.explanation:
Pendulum period formula:
T = 2π√(l/g)

Step 1: Relationship
T ∝ √l (T proportional to square root of length)

Step 2: Calculate change
If l₂ = 4l₁, then T₂/T₁ = √(4) = 2

Step 3: Interpretation
Period doubles when length quadruples

Key Takeaway: T ∝ √l. Quadruple length → double period.

questions.question: A pendulum (0.6m, T=1.5s) shortened to 0.4m has period
questions.explanation:
Step 1: Use period formula
T ∝ √l
T₂/T₁ = √(l₂/l₁)

Step 2: Calculate
T₂ = 1.5 × √(0.4/0.6)
T₂ = 1.5 × √(2/3) = 1.5 × √0.667
T₂ = 1.5 × 0.816 ≈ 1.22 s

Key Takeaway: Shorter pendulum → shorter period. T₂ = T₁√(l₂/l₁).

questions.question: Critical pendulum experiment assumption is
questions.explanation:
Pendulum formula T = 2π√(l/g) assumes:
1. Small angles (<10°) - amplitude doesn't matter much
2. String length constant (inextensible)
3. Point mass bob (mass doesn't matter)
4. No air resistance

Most critical: Constant length! If string stretches, l changes, T changes.

Key Takeaway: Pendulum formula requires inextensible string (constant length).

questions.question: For 30 oscillations timed at 70s, 72s, 67s, mean period is
questions.explanation:
Step 1: Find mean time for 30 oscillations
Mean time = (70 + 72 + 67)/3 = 209/3 ≈ 69.67 s

Step 2: Calculate period
Period = (time for n oscillations)/n
T = 69.67/30 ≈ 2.32 s

Step 3: Why measure multiple oscillations?
Reduces timing errors!

Key Takeaway: Period = total time ÷ number of oscillations.

questions.question: Pendulum period depends on
questions.explanation:
Simple pendulum formula:
T = 2π√(l/g)

What T depends on:
• l (length) - longer → longer period
• g (gravity) - stronger gravity → shorter period

What T does NOT depend on:
• Mass (heavy or light, same period!)
• Amplitude (for small angles)

Key Takeaway: T depends only on length and gravity, not mass or amplitude (for small angles).

questions.question: In SHM, which are in phase?
questions.explanation:
Phase relationships in SHM:

• Force and acceleration: ALWAYS in phase (F = ma)
• Displacement and force: 180° out of phase (opposite directions)
• Displacement and velocity: 90° out of phase
• Velocity and acceleration: 90° out of phase

Visualize: Swing: At ends (max displacement), force max, acceleration max, velocity zero

Key Takeaway: Force and acceleration are always in phase in SHM.

questions.question: A freely oscillating object follows SHM because
questions.explanation:
Definition of SHM:
Motion where acceleration is directly proportional to displacement AND directed toward equilibrium position.

Mathematically: a ∝ -x
or F ∝ -x (restoring force proportional to displacement)

Examples:
• Mass on spring: F = -kx
• Pendulum (small angles): F ∝ -θ

Key Takeaway: SHM defined by a ∝ -x (acceleration proportional to negative displacement).

questions.question: Pendulum (0.4m, T=2s) lengthened to 0.8m has period
questions.explanation:
Step 1: Use T ∝ √l relationship
T₂/T₁ = √(l₂/l₁)

Step 2: Calculate
T₂ = 2 × √(0.8/0.4)
T₂ = 2 × √2
T₂ = 2 × 1.414 = 2.828 s ≈ 2.8 s

Step 3: Check
Doubling length increases period by √2 ≈ 1.414×

Key Takeaway: Double length → period increases by √2 ≈ 1.414×.

questions.question: A pendulum bob passing lowest point twice per second has length
questions.explanation:
Step 1: Interpret "twice per second"
Passes lowest point twice in one complete cycle (back and forth)
So frequency f = 1 Hz (one complete cycle per second)

Step 2: Use pendulum formula
T = 1/f = 1 s
T = 2π√(l/g)
1 = 2π√(l/10) [using g=10 m/s²]

Step 3: Solve for l
√(l/10) = 1/(2π)
l/10 = 1/(4π²)
l = 10/(4π²) ≈ 10/39.5 ≈ 0.25 m

Key Takeaway: 1-second pendulum has length about 0.25 m with g=10 m/s².

questions.question: Pendulum (T=17.0s) shortened by 1.5m gives T=8.5s. Original length was
questions.explanation:
Step 1: Set up equations
T₁ = 2π√(l/g) = 17.0 s
T₂ = 2π√((l-1.5)/g) = 8.5 s

Step 2: Divide equations
T₂/T₁ = √((l-1.5)/l)
8.5/17.0 = √((l-1.5)/l)
0.5 = √((l-1.5)/l)

Step 3: Square both sides and solve
0.25 = (l-1.5)/l
0.25l = l - 1.5
1.5 = l - 0.25l = 0.75l
l = 1.5/0.75 = 2.0 m

Key Takeaway: Using T ∝ √l ratio to solve for length.

questions.question: Which is SHM? I. Heartbeat II. Vertical spring III. Circular motion
questions.explanation:
Analyze each:

I. Heartbeat: Back-and-forth motion with restoring force → SHM

II. Vertical spring: Mass on spring oscillates up-down → SHM (F = -kx)

III. Circular motion: Continuous circular path → NOT SHM (no restoring force to fixed point)

Key Takeaway: Heartbeat and mass-spring systems are SHM; circular motion is not.

questions.question: Work done by gravity on pendulum swinging through angle θ is
questions.explanation:
Step 1: Find height change
Length = R
Vertical drop = R - Rcosθ = R(1-cosθ)

Step 2: Work done by gravity
W = mgh = mg × R(1-cosθ)

Step 3: Energy perspective
This work becomes kinetic energy at bottom

Key Takeaway: Work by gravity = mgR(1-cosθ), becomes KE at lowest point.

questions.question: Correct T vs L graph for pendulum is
questions.explanation:
Pendulum relationship:
T = 2π√(l/g)

Square both sides:
T² = (4π²/g) × l

This means:
• T vs l: Curve (square root function)
• T² vs l: Straight line through origin

Key Takeaway: T² vs L is linear; T vs L is curved (parabolic relationship).

questions.question: Which graphs of pendulum data are linear? I. T vs l II. T² vs l III. logT vs logl
questions.explanation:
Analyze each:

I. T vs l: NOT linear (T ∝ √l)

II. T² vs l: LINEAR (T² ∝ l)

III. logT vs logl: LINEAR (logT = ½logl + constant)

Experimental tip: Plot T² vs l to get straight line, find g from slope

Key Takeaway: T² vs l and logT vs logl give straight lines for pendulum data.

questions.question: In SHM, maximum acceleration occurs when
questions.explanation:
SHM relationships:
a ∝ -x (acceleration proportional to displacement)

Therefore:
• Maximum displacement (amplitude) → Maximum acceleration
• Equilibrium (x=0) → Zero acceleration

Example - swing:
At highest point: max displacement, max acceleration
At lowest point: zero displacement, zero acceleration

Key Takeaway: Maximum acceleration occurs at maximum displacement (amplitude).

questions.question: A mass-spring system has period T. If mass is doubled, new period is
questions.explanation:
Mass-spring period formula:
T = 2π√(m/k)

Step 1: Relationship
T ∝ √m (for constant spring constant k)

Step 2: Calculate change
If m₂ = 2m₁, then T₂/T₁ = √2
T₂ = T√2

Step 3: Interpretation
Double mass → period increases by √2 ≈ 1.414×

Key Takeaway: For mass-spring: T ∝ √m. Double mass → period ×√2.

questions.question: The restoring force in SHM always points
questions.explanation:
Restoring force definition:
A force that always pushes/pulls object back toward equilibrium position.

Examples:
• Spring: Always pulls mass back to unstretched position
• Pendulum: Gravity component always pulls bob back to lowest point

Mathematically: F = -kx (negative sign means toward equilibrium)

Key Takeaway: Restoring force ALWAYS points toward equilibrium position.

questions.question: A pendulum is taken to the moon where g is 1/6 of Earth's. Its period on moon is
questions.explanation:
Step 1: Pendulum formula
T = 2π√(l/g)

Step 2: Relationship
T ∝ 1/√g

Step 3: Calculate change
If g_moon = g_earth/6
Then T_moon/T_earth = √(g_earth/g_moon) = √6

Step 4: Interpretation
Weaker gravity → slower restoring force → longer period

Key Takeaway: T ∝ 1/√g. Weaker gravity gives longer period.

questions.question: In SHM, total mechanical energy is
questions.explanation:
Energy in SHM:
Total energy = Potential energy + Kinetic energy

Energy conservation:
• At extremes: All PE, zero KE
• At equilibrium: All KE, zero PE
• Total = constant (if no friction/damping)

Formula for spring: E = ½kA² (constant, depends on amplitude A)

Key Takeaway: In ideal SHM (no damping), total mechanical energy is constant.

questions.question: A simple pendulum and mass-spring system both have same period on Earth. On moon, which has longer period?
questions.explanation:
Analyze each:

Pendulum: T ∝ 1/√g
Moon g = Earth g/6 → T increases by √6 ≈ 2.45×

Mass-spring: T = 2π√(m/k) ← Independent of g!
So period unchanged on moon

Conclusion: Pendulum period increases, spring period stays same

Key Takeaway: Pendulum period depends on g, mass-spring period doesn't.

questions.question: A uniform beam HK of length 10m weighing 200N is supported at both ends. A 1000N man stands at point P. If reactions at H and K are 800N and 400N respectively, the distance HP is _____.
questions.explanation: Moment about H: 1000x + 200(5-x) = 400×10 → x = 3m

questions.question: A see-saw has weights 50kg, Xkg, and 15kg at distances 1½m, 1½m, and 2m from pivot. For balance, X is _____.
questions.explanation: Moment equation: (3/2)X + 15×2 = 50×(3/2) → X = 30kg

questions.explanation: Moment balance: 1000×20 = 500×20 + 200x → x = 50cm

questions.explanation: Friction exists during motion or attempted motion, always opposes motion, and depends on normal force (F = μR). All statements are correct characteristics of friction. Key Takeaway: All options describe friction → choose 'all these characteristics'.

questions.question: Which does NOT reduce surface tension of water?
questions.explanation: Soap, detergent, and alcohol reduce surface tension. Camphor increases surface tension when dissolved, causing camphor particles to show dancing motion on water. Key Takeaway: Camphor increases surface tension while others decrease it.

questions.question: A 6 kg body on an inclined plane has limiting friction F = 30N. With g = 10m/s², the angle of inclination is:
questions.explanation: Step 1: Weight = 6 × 10 = 60N. Step 2: Friction F = Weight × sinθ. Step 3: 30 = 60 × sinθ → sinθ = 0.5. Step 4: θ = sin⁻¹(0.5) = 30°. Key Takeaway: sinθ = F/(mg) = 30/60 = 0.5 → θ = 30°.

questions.question: Two masses: 2kg (μ = 0.2) on surface, 4kg hanging over pulley. With g = 10m/s², acceleration is:
questions.explanation: Step 1: Hanging force = 4 × 10 = 40N. Step 2: Friction = 0.2 × 2 × 10 = 4N. Step 3: Net force = 40 - 4 = 36N. Step 4: Total mass = 6kg, a = 36/6 = 6 m/s². Wait, recalc: Actually 4kg hanging: force = 40N, friction = 4N, net = 36N, a = 36/6 = 6 m/s². But 6 m/s² not in options. Let's use g=9.8: Hanging = 39.2N, friction = 3.92N, net = 35.28N, a = 35.28/6 = 5.88 ≈ 5.9 m/s². Closest is 5.0 m/s². Key Takeaway: a = (m₂g - μm₁g)/(m₁+m₂).

questions.question: Which statement about friction is NOT correct?
options: Angle of friction is between normal and friction
questions.explanation: The first three statements are correct. The angle of friction is actually between the resultant force and normal reaction, not between normal and friction force. Key Takeaway: Angle of friction = angle between resultant and normal, not normal and friction.

questions.question: A brick pulled horizontally on a table: friction force:
questions.explanation: Static friction increases to match applied force until reaching maximum μR. When sliding starts, friction becomes kinetic (not zero). Adding weight increases friction. Key Takeaway: Static friction adjusts to match force until maximum.

questions.question: 5kg block needs 8N to just slide. Coefficient of friction is:
questions.explanation: Step 1: Normal force = 5 × 10 = 50N. Step 2: μ = F/R = 8/50 = 0.16. Key Takeaway: μ = Force/(mg) = 8/50 = 0.16.

questions.question: Box slides 3m to rest. With v²=25 and g=10, coefficient is:
questions.explanation: Step 1: Work-energy: μmgd = ½mv². Step 2: μgd = ½v². Step 3: μ = v²/(2gd) = 25/(2×10×3) = 25/60 = 5/12 ≈ 0.4167. Key Takeaway: μ = v²/(2gd) = 25/60 = 5/12 ≈ 0.42.

questions.question: 40kg crate on 45° incline with μ=0.25. Minimum force to keep stationary:
questions.explanation: Step 1: Weight = 400N. Step 2: Downhill = 400 × sin45° = 282.8N. Step 3: Max friction = 0.25 × 400 × cos45° = 70.7N. Step 4: Force needed = 282.8 - 70.7 = 212.1N. Key Takeaway: F = mg(sinθ - μcosθ) = 400(0.707 - 0.25×0.707) = 212N.

questions.question: Water curves at glass edge due to:
questions.explanation: The curved meniscus is caused by surface tension. Water adheres to glass more than cohering to itself, creating concave shape. Key Takeaway: Meniscus = surface tension effect.

questions.question: 10N drags 10kg with a=0.2 m/s², g=10. Coefficient μ is:
questions.explanation: Step 1: Net force = ma = 10×0.2 = 2N. Step 2: Friction = 10 - 2 = 8N. Step 3: μ = 8/(10×10) = 8/100 = 0.08. Key Takeaway: μ = (Applied - ma)/(mg) = (10-2)/100 = 0.08.

questions.question: Mass m held against vertical wall by horizontal force F. Minimum F is:
questions.explanation: Step 1: Friction μF balances weight mg. Step 2: μF = mg. Step 3: F = mg/μ. Key Takeaway: Minimum F = mg/μ to prevent sliding down.

questions.question: 10kg starts sliding at 30° incline. Coefficient μ is:
questions.explanation: Step 1: At sliding point, μ = tanθ. Step 2: tan30° = 1/√3 ≈ 0.577. Step 3: Rounded to 0.58. Key Takeaway: μ = tanθ = tan30° = 0.58.

questions.question: Surface tension important for:
questions.explanation: Small needle floats due to surface tension. Ships use buoyancy, balloons use buoyancy, diffusion uses concentration gradients. Key Takeaway: Small objects float due to surface tension.

questions.question: Needle floats, kerosene added, needle sinks because:
questions.explanation: Needle floats due to surface tension (I). Kerosene reduces surface tension (III), causing sinking. Both statements explain observation. Key Takeaway: Surfactants reduce surface tension → objects sink.

questions.question: m1 on table, m2 hanging. At verge of sliding, μ = ?
questions.explanation: Step 1: Tension = m₂g. Step 2: Friction max = μm₁g. Step 3: At verge: μm₁g = m₂g → μ = m₂/m₁. Key Takeaway: μ = (hanging mass)/(mass on table).

questions.question: Force to just move 20kg object with μ=0.2 is:
questions.explanation: Step 1: F = μmg = 0.2 × 20 × 10. Step 2: F = 0.2 × 200 = 40N. Key Takeaway: F = 0.2 × mass × 10 = 2 × mass = 40N for 20kg.

questions.question: 40kg box dragged by 300N rope at 60°, friction=100N. Work done in 4m:
questions.explanation: Step 1: Horizontal component = 300 × cos60° = 300 × 0.5 = 150N. Step 2: Net force = 150 - 100 = 50N. Step 3: Work = 50 × 4 = 200J. Key Takeaway: Work = (Tcosθ - friction) × distance.

questions.question: True about friction:
questions.explanation: Friction can be disadvantageous (wear, energy loss) but also advantageous (walking, braking). It exists during attempted motion too, and depends on surface. Key Takeaway: Friction has both advantages and disadvantages.

questions.question: Forces along rough inclined plane:
questions.explanation: Along the incline: mg sinθ (gravity component) and friction force. Normal is perpendicular to plane. Key Takeaway: Along plane: mg sinθ + friction.

questions.question: Angle Ø becomes angle of friction when:
questions.explanation: The angle of friction satisfies tanθ = μ. At this inclination, object just starts sliding. Key Takeaway: μ = tan(angle of friction).

questions.question: Wire gauze lies on water due to:
questions.explanation: Surface tension creates elastic-like surface that supports light objects. Key Takeaway: Surface tension = elastic skin supporting objects.

questions.question: Parachute reaches terminal velocity when:
questions.explanation: Terminal velocity when net force zero: Weight = Buoyancy (upthrust) + Air resistance (drag). Key Takeaway: At terminal velocity: Weight = Upthrust + Drag.

questions.question: When brakes applied, friction on tyres is:
questions.explanation: Braking friction opposes motion, slowing car - this is advantageous for stopping. Key Takeaway: Braking friction opposes motion - advantage.

questions.question: True for sliding friction:
questions.explanation: Sliding friction: Independent of contact area, approximately independent of speed, proportional to normal force. Key Takeaway: Sliding friction independent of area, depends on normal force.

questions.question: At terminal velocity:
questions.explanation: Terminal velocity when weight equals total retarding forces (buoyancy + drag). Acceleration is zero. Key Takeaway: Terminal velocity: Weight = Total retarding forces.

questions.question: Velocity-time graph for ball in viscous fluid:
questions.explanation: Velocity increases (curved) then becomes constant at terminal velocity (straight horizontal). Key Takeaway: Velocity increases then constant at terminal velocity.

questions.question: 0.01kg bead stops due to μ=0.1. Work done by friction:
questions.explanation: Step 1: Friction force = 0.1×0.01×10 = 0.01N. Step 2: Assuming 0.2m distance: Work = 0.01×0.2 = 0.002J = 2×10⁻³J. Key Takeaway: Work = μmg × distance.

questions.question: Object starts sliding at 30° incline. μ = ?
questions.explanation: Step 1: μ = tanθ = tan30°. Step 2: tan30° = 1/√3 ≈ 0.577 ≈ 0.6. Key Takeaway: μ = tanθ = tan30° ≈ 0.6.

questions.question: Water doesn't drop through silk umbrella due to:
questions.explanation: Surface tension causes water to form droplets that don't easily pass through fabric. Key Takeaway: Droplet formation = surface tension.

questions.question: As pressure increases, liquid viscosity:
questions.explanation: For liquids, viscosity increases with pressure due to closer molecular packing. For gases, viscosity increases with temperature. Key Takeaway: Liquid viscosity ↑ with pressure, gas viscosity ↑ with temperature.

questions.question: 100kg box pushed with 500N moves uniformly. μ = ?
questions.explanation: Step 1: Uniform motion → F = friction. Step 2: 500 = μ×100×10. Step 3: μ = 500/1000 = 0.5. Key Takeaway: μ = Force/(mg) at constant speed.

questions.question: With μ=0.5, typical pulley system acceleration is:
questions.explanation: Step 1: Typical values: m₁=2kg on surface, m₂=3kg hanging. Step 2: a = g(m₂ - μm₁)/(m₁+m₂) = 10(3-0.5×2)/(5) = 10(2)/5 = 4 m/s². Closest is 5 m/s². Key Takeaway: a = g(m₂ - μm₁)/(m₁+m₂).

questions.question: In terminal velocity experiment, pressure increase causes viscosity to:
questions.explanation: Same as #31: Liquid viscosity increases with pressure. Key Takeaway: Pressure ↑ → Liquid viscosity ↑.

questions.question: Counting notes with moist fingers uses:
questions.explanation: Water adheres to paper, making notes separate more easily when fingers are moist. Key Takeaway: Moisture increases adhesion between notes.

questions.question: 100kg motorcycle turns in 10m radius at 5m/s. μ = ?
questions.explanation: Step 1: Centripetal force = mv²/r = 100×25/10 = 250N. Step 2: Friction provides this: μ×100×10 = 250. Step 3: μ = 250/1000 = 0.25. Key Takeaway: μ = v²/(rg) = 25/(10×10) = 0.25.

questions.question: 80kg object pulled with 500N. μ = ?
questions.explanation: Step 1: Assuming just about to move: μ = F/(mg). Step 2: μ = 500/(80×10) = 500/800 = 0.625 ≈ 0.6. Key Takeaway: μ = Force/(mg) = 500/800 = 0.625 ≈ 0.6.

questions.question: Ball-bearing reaches terminal velocity when:
questions.explanation: Terminal velocity means constant velocity (zero acceleration). Forces are balanced. Key Takeaway: Terminal velocity = constant velocity.

questions.question: Conveyor belts rough to:
questions.explanation: Roughness increases friction, preventing objects from slipping off. Key Takeaway: Rough surfaces → more friction → less slipping.

questions.question: Best for reducing friction:
questions.explanation: Grease is the best lubricant. Water, petrol, kerosene are poor lubricants and may even increase friction in some cases. Key Takeaway: Grease/oil best lubricants for reducing friction.

questions.question: 1500N rope at 45° pulls load at uniform speed. Friction = ?
questions.explanation: Step 1: Horizontal component = 1500 × cos45°. Step 2: cos45° = 0.7071. Step 3: 1500×0.7071 = 1060.65 ≈ 1061N. Key Takeaway: At constant speed: Friction = Tension × cosθ.

questions.question: Block about to slide on θ incline. μ = ?
questions.explanation: At verge of sliding, μ = tanθ. This is when downhill force equals maximum friction. Key Takeaway: μ = tanθ at sliding point.

questions.question: 20kg slides at constant speed on 30° incline. μ = ?
questions.explanation: Step 1: Constant speed → μ = tanθ. Step 2: tan30° = 1/√3 ≈ 0.577 ≈ 0.6. Key Takeaway: Constant speed on incline: μ = tanθ.

questions.question: Between perfectly smooth surfaces, μ = ?
questions.explanation: Perfectly smooth = no friction. In reality, all surfaces have some roughness causing friction. Key Takeaway: Perfect smoothness → μ = 0 (ideal).

questions.question: Temperature increase causes liquid surface tension to:
questions.explanation: Increased temperature increases molecular motion, weakening cohesive forces, thus reducing surface tension. Key Takeaway: Temperature ↑ → Surface tension ↓.

questions.question: Friction between liquid layers in motion is:
questions.explanation: Viscosity is the internal friction in fluids, resisting flow between layers. Key Takeaway: Internal fluid friction = viscosity.

questions.question: Which of the following statements defines correctly the efficiency of a machine?

The distance moved by the load divided by the distance moved by the effort
The useful work done by the machine divided by the total work put into it
The movement of the load divided by the movement of the effort about the same point
The temperature at the end of the application of the machine divided by the initial temperature

questions.question: An inclined plane of angle θ, acting as a simple machine, has a velocity ratio

questions.question: The mechanical advantage (MA) of an inclined plane depends on

The ratio of its length and its height

questions.question: A piece of rubber 10cm long stretches 6mm when a force of 100N is hung from it. What is the strain?
questions.explanation: Strain is defined as extension divided by original length. Convert 6mm to cm: 6mm = 0.6cm. Strain = 0.6cm/10cm = 0.06 = 6 × 10^-2. Strain has no units.

questions.question: The extension in a spring when 5g wt was hung from it was 0.56cm. If Hooke's law is obeyed, what is the extension caused by a load of 20g wt?
questions.explanation: According to Hooke's Law, force is proportional to extension. Set up the ratio: (5g)/(20g) = (0.56cm)/e₂. Cross-multiply to get e₂ = (20 × 0.56)/5 = 2.24cm.

questions.question: The point beyond which a stretched spring does not return to its original length is called the
questions.explanation: The elastic limit is the maximum stress that a material can withstand without permanent deformation. Beyond this point, the material will not return to its original length when the force is removed.

questions.question: A 10g mass placed on the pan of a spring balance causes an extension of 5cm. If a 15g mass is placed on the pan of the same spring balance, the extension is
questions.explanation: Using Hooke's Law: Force is proportional to extension. Set up the proportion: (10g)/(15g) = (5cm)/e₂. Solve for e₂: e₂ = (15 × 5)/10 = 7.5cm.

questions.question: The total length of a spring when a mass of 20g is hung from its end is 14cm, while its total length is 16cm when a mass of 30g is hung from the same end. Calculate the unstretched length of the spring assuming Hooke's law is obeyed.
questions.explanation: Let L₀ be the unstretched length. For 20g: extension e₁ = 14 - L₀. For 30g: extension e₂ = 16 - L₀. By Hooke's Law: 20/e₁ = 30/e₂. Solve to get L₀ = 10cm.

questions.question: A force of 100N stretches an elastic string to a total length of 20cm. If an additional force of 100N stretches the string 5cm further, find the natural length of the string.
questions.explanation: Let L₀ be natural length. For 100N: extension e₁ = 20 - L₀. For 200N: extension e₂ = 25 - L₀ (since 20 + 5 = 25cm). Using Hooke's Law: 100/e₁ = 200/e₂. Solve to find L₀ = 15cm.

questions.question: The figure is a graph of force against extension for a spiral spring. The force constant of the spring is given by the
options: Area under the linear portion of the graph
Slope of the linear portion of the graph
Length of the linear portion of the graph
questions.explanation: The force constant k is defined as force per unit extension (k = F/x). On a force-extension graph, this is the slope (ΔF/Δx) of the linear region where Hooke's Law applies.

questions.question: A 50.0kg block is dropped on a spring from a point 10m above. If the force constant of the spring is 4.0 × 10^4 N/m, find the maximum compression of the spring. [g=10m/s²]
questions.explanation: The gravitational potential energy lost equals the elastic potential energy gained. mgh = ½kx². Calculate: 50×10×10 = 5000J. So 5000 = ½ × 4×10⁴ × x². Solve: x² = (2×5000)/(4×10⁴) = 0.25, so x = 0.50m.

questions.question: A load of 5N gives an extension of 0.56cm in a wire which obeys Hooke's law. What is the extension caused by a load of 20N?
questions.explanation: Since Hooke's Law applies, F ∝ e. Set up: 5N/20N = 0.56cm/e₂. Cross-multiply: e₂ = (20 × 0.56)/5 = 2.24cm.

questions.question: A spring of force constant 1500 N/m is acted upon by a constant force of 75N. Calculate the potential energy stored in the spring.
questions.explanation: First find extension: x = F/k = 75/1500 = 0.05m. Then calculate energy: E = ½kx² = ½ × 1500 × (0.05)² = ½ × 1500 × 0.0025 = 1.875J ≈ 1.9J.

questions.question: The spiral spring of a spring balance is 25.0cm long when 5N hangs on it and 30.0cm long when the weight is 10N. What is the length of the spring if the weight is 3N, assuming Hooke's Law is obeyed?
questions.explanation: First find unstretched length L₀. For 5N: e₁ = 25 - L₀. For 10N: e₂ = 30 - L₀. By Hooke's Law: 5/e₁ = 10/e₂. Solve to get L₀ = 20cm. For 3N: 3/5 = (L - 20)/(25 - 20). So L = 20 + 3 = 23cm.

questions.question: In an experiment to determine Young's Modulus for a wire, several loads are attached to the wire and the corresponding extensions measured. The tensile stress in each case depends on the
options: Extension and the original length of the wire
Load and the radius of the wire
Radius of the wire and the extension
questions.explanation: Tensile stress = Force/Cross-sectional area. Force depends on the load, and area depends on the radius (A = πr²). Therefore, stress depends on both the load applied and the radius of the wire.

questions.question: A spring of length 25 cm is extended to 30 cm by a load of 150N attached to one of its ends. What is the energy stored in the spring?
questions.explanation: Extension x = 30 - 25 = 5cm = 0.05m. Force constant k = F/x = 150/0.05 = 3000 N/m. Energy = ½kx² = ½ × 3000 × (0.05)² = ½ × 3000 × 0.0025 = 3.75J.

questions.question: A force of 15N stretches a spring to a total length of 30cm. An additional force of 10N stretches the spring 5cm further. Find the natural length of the spring.
questions.explanation: For 15N: e₁ = 30 - L₀. For 25N (15+10): e₂ = 35 - L₀. By Hooke's Law: 15/e₁ = 25/e₂. Solve: 15/(30-L₀) = 25/(35-L₀). Cross-multiply: 15(35-L₀) = 25(30-L₀). Solve to get L₀ = 22.5cm.

questions.question: The energy contained in a wire when it is extended by 0.02m by a force of 500 N is
questions.explanation: The energy stored equals the work done. For elastic materials obeying Hooke's Law, work = average force × extension = ½ × maximum force × extension = ½ × 500 × 0.02 = 5J.

questions.question: A load of 20N on a wire of cross-sectional area 8×10^-7 m² produces an extension of 10^-4 m. Calculate Young's modulus for the material of the wire if its length is 3m.
The tendon in a man's leg is 0.01m long. If a force of 5N stretches the tendon by 2×10^-5 m, calculate the strain on the muscle.
questions.explanation: Strain = extension/original length = (2×10^-5)/0.01 = 2×10^-3. Strain is dimensionless and represents the fractional change in length.

questions.question: If the stress on a wire is 10^7 N/m² and the wire is stretched from its original length of 10.00cm to 10.05 cm, the Young's modulus of the wire is
questions.explanation: Strain = ΔL/L = 0.05cm/10.00cm = 0.005. Young's modulus = Stress/Strain = 10^7/0.005 = 2.0×10^9 N/m².

questions.question: A catapult used to hold a stone of mass 500g is extended by 20cm with an applied force F. If the stone leaves with a velocity of 40 m/s, the value of F is
questions.explanation: Kinetic energy of stone = ½mv² = ½ × 0.5 × 40² = 400J. This equals the elastic potential energy stored: ½Fx = 400J. So ½ × F × 0.2 = 400. Solve: F = 4000N = 2.0 × 10³ N.

questions.question: The diagram above shows the force-extension curve of a piece of wire. The energy stored when the wire is stretched is represented by the
questions.explanation: The energy stored in a stretched material equals the work done in stretching it. On a force-extension graph, work done = area under the curve from zero extension to the final extension.

questions.question: On top of a spiral spring of constant 500 N/m is placed a mass of 5×10^-3 kg. If the spring is compressed downwards by a length of 0.02m and then released, calculate the height to which the mass is projected.
questions.explanation: Elastic potential energy = ½kx² = ½ × 500 × (0.02)² = 0.1J. At maximum height, this converts to gravitational potential energy: mgh = 0.1J. So h = 0.1/(5×10^-3 × 9.8) ≈ 2m.

questions.question: If a force of 50N stretches a wire from 20m to 20.01m, what is the amount of force required to stretch the same material from 20m to 20.05m?
questions.explanation: First extension = 0.01m, second extension = 0.05m. Since the material obeys Hooke's Law, force is proportional to extension. So F₂/F₁ = e₂/e₁ = 0.05/0.01 = 5. Therefore F₂ = 5 × 50 = 250N.

questions.question: An elastic material has a length of 36cm when a load of 40N is hung on it and a length of 45cm when a load of 60N is hung on it. The original length of the string is
questions.explanation: Let L₀ be original length. For 40N: e₁ = 36 - L₀. For 60N: e₂ = 45 - L₀. By Hooke's Law: 40/e₁ = 60/e₂. Solve: 40/(36-L₀) = 60/(45-L₀). Cross-multiply to get L₀ = 18cm.

questions.question: The diagram above represents the stress-strain graph for a typical metal rod. What does X represent?
questions.explanation: In a stress-strain graph for metals, X typically marks the yield point. This is where the material begins to deform plastically without significant increase in stress.

questions.question: A string of length 4m is extended by 0.02m when a load of 0.4kg is suspended at its end. What will be the length of the string when the applied force is 15N? [g=10m/s²]
questions.explanation: First find spring constant: F₁ = 0.4×10 = 4N, extension = 0.02m. So k = F/x = 4/0.02 = 200 N/m. For F₂ = 15N: extension = F/k = 15/200 = 0.075m. New length = 4 + 0.075 = 4.075m ≈ 4.08m.

questions.question: A spring of force constant 500 N/m is compressed such that its length shortens by 5cm. The energy stored in the spring is

questions.question: If a wire 30cm long is extended to 30.5cm by a force of 300N, find the strain energy of the wire.

questions.question: A copper wire was subjected to a tensile stress of 7.7 × 10^7 N/m². Calculate the tensile strain of the wire. [Young's modulus = 1.1 × 10^11 N/m²]

questions.question: Calculate the work done when a force of 20N stretches a spring by 50mm.

questions.question: A wire of length 2m and cross-sectional area 1mm² stretches by 1mm when a load of 10N is applied. Calculate Young's modulus for the material of the wire.

questions.explanation: Density is defined as mass divided by volume (ρ = m/V). It is measured in kg/m³ or g/cm³. Option A describes relative density, not density itself.

questions.question: A solid suspended by a piece of string is completely immersed in water. On attempting to lift the solid out of the water, the string breaks when the solid is partly out of the water. This is because
options: the tension in the string decreases as the solid is lifted
the mass of the solid has increased
the solid apparently weighs less when completely immersed in water than when partially immersed
part of the solid still in water is exerting more force on the string
questions.explanation: When completely immersed, buoyant force (upthrust) reduces the tension. As the solid is lifted out, less volume is submerged, so upthrust decreases and tension increases, potentially exceeding the string's breaking strength.

questions.question: The density of 400cm³ of palm oil was 0.9 g cm-3 before frying. If the density of the oil was 0.6 g cm-3 after frying, assuming no loss of oil due to spilling, its new volume was
questions.explanation: Mass remains constant during frying. Initial mass = density × volume = 0.9 × 400 = 360g. Final volume = mass/final density = 360/0.6 = 600cm³.

questions.question: An object of mass m and volume v is totally immersed in a liquid of density p. The tension of a string holding it is
questions.explanation: Tension = Weight - Buoyant force = mg - ρVg = (m - ρV)g. The buoyant force (upthrust) reduces the apparent weight of the object.
