questions.explanation: In a stationary wave pattern, the distance between a node (N) and the adjacent antinode (A) is always λ/4.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is (are) NOT correct? I. Pressure changes do not affect the speed of sound in air. II. The velocity of sound increases with temperature. III. The quality of a note depends only on its frequency.
questions.explanation: I is correct: speed is independent of pressure for an ideal gas. II is correct: v ∝ √T. III is incorrect: quality (timbre) depends on the harmonic content (number and relative intensities of overtones), not just the fundamental frequency.

questions.text: Of two identical tuning forks with natural frequency 256 Hz, one is loaded so that 4 beats per second are heard when they are sounded together. What is the frequency of the loaded tuning fork?
questions.explanation: Beats occur due to the difference in frequencies. Beat frequency = |f₁ - f₂| = 4 Hz. Since one fork is loaded (wax added), its frequency decreases. Therefore, the frequency of the loaded fork is 256 Hz - 4 Hz = 252 Hz.

questions.text: A wave of frequency 10Hz forms a stationary wave pattern in a medium where the velocity is 20cms⁻¹. The distance between adjacent nodes is
questions.explanation: First, find the wavelength λ. v = fλ, so λ = v / f = 20 cm/s / 10 Hz = 2 cm. In a stationary wave, the distance between two adjacent nodes is half the wavelength. Distance = λ/2 = 2 cm / 2 = 1.0 cm.

questions.text: In the figure below a resonance tube experiment is performed using one tuning fork. As the water level is lowered the first resonance is obtained when the length of the air column l = λ/4. The second resonance is obtained when l equals
questions.explanation: For a closed pipe, the first resonance occurs at l₁ = λ/4. The second resonance occurs at the next possible length where a node is at the water surface and an antinode at the open end, which is l₂ = 3λ/4.

questions.text: Which of the following is true of the loudness of sound? It
options: A. Depends on the square of the amplitude of the vibrating body
B. Is proportional to the distance of the observer from the source of the sound
questions.answer: A. Depends on the square of the amplitude of the vibrating body
questions.explanation: The loudness of a sound is related to the intensity of the wave, which is proportional to the square of the amplitude of the vibration (I ∝ A²).

questions.text: Which of the following instruments has a pure tone?
questions.explanation: A pure tone is a sound with a sinusoidal waveform, meaning it consists of only a single frequency. A tuning fork produces a sound very close to a pure tone. Other instruments like the guitar and siren produce complex tones with many harmonics.

questions.text: The lowest note emitted by a stretched string has a frequency of 40Hz. How many overtones are there between 40Hz and 150Hz?
questions.explanation: The fundamental frequency is 40 Hz. The overtones for a string are harmonics: 2nd harmonic (1st overtone) = 80 Hz, 3rd harmonic (2nd overtone) = 120 Hz, 4th harmonic (3rd overtone) = 160 Hz. So, between 40 Hz and 150 Hz, we have the 80 Hz and 120 Hz overtones. That is 2 overtones.

questions.text: When the length l of a piece of wire under constant tension is varied, the relationship of the frequency of vibration f with l is
questions.explanation: For a vibrating string, the fundamental frequency is inversely proportional to its length (f ∝ 1/L), provided the tension and mass per unit length remain constant.

questions.text: A note is called an octave of another note when
options: A. Its frequency is twice that of the first note
B. Its frequency is half that of the first note
C. The notes have the same fundamental frequency
D. Its periodic time is twice that of the first note
questions.answer: A. Its frequency is twice that of the first note
questions.explanation: An octave is the interval between one musical pitch and another with double its frequency.

questions.text: A slight loading of a tuning fork has the effect of
questions.explanation: Adding a small weight (loading) to the prongs of a tuning fork increases its effective mass. This decreases its natural frequency of vibration.

questions.text: Two strings of the same length and under the same tension give notes of frequencies in the ratio 4:1. The masses of the strings are in the corresponding ratio of
questions.explanation: The frequency of a string is inversely proportional to the square root of its mass per unit length (f ∝ 1/√μ). Therefore, f₁/f₂ = √(μ₂/μ₁). Given f₁/f₂ = 4/1, so 4/1 = √(μ₂/μ₁). Squaring both sides: 16/1 = μ₂/μ₁. Therefore, the ratio of masses (which is the same as the ratio of mass per unit length for same length) is μ₁ : μ₂ = 1 : 16.

questions.text: In which of the following diagrams is the length of the tube equal to one wavelength? [Diagrams not shown]
questions.explanation: This question requires visual interpretation of standing wave patterns in tubes. The length corresponding to one wavelength would be a tube showing, for example, two nodes and two antinodes for an open pipe (fundamental wavelength λ = 2L).

questions.text: Two tuning forks of frequencies 256Hz and 260Hz are sounded close to each other. What is the frequency of the beats produced?
questions.explanation: The beat frequency is the absolute difference between the frequencies of the two tuning forks: |256 Hz - 260 Hz| = 4 Hz.

questions.text: A note is the octave of another note if it has
options: A. frequency twice that of the first note
B. Frequency half that of the first note
C. The same frequency as the first one
D. A frequency between 40Hz and eight times that of the first note
questions.answer: A. frequency twice that of the first note
questions.explanation: An octave corresponds to a doubling of frequency.

questions.text: The relationship between l and the wavelength λ of the stationary wave is [Figure needed]
questions.explanation: This requires the figure. A common result for the second resonance in a closed pipe is that the length l = 3λ/4, which can be rearranged to 4l = 3λ.

questions.text: Determine the distance between the consecutive antinodes XX if the wavelength is 66cm.
questions.explanation: The distance between two consecutive antinodes in a stationary wave is half the wavelength. Distance = λ/2 = 66 cm / 2 = 33 cm. (33cm is not an option, 30cm is closest). Alternatively, if the question means nodes, distance between nodes is also λ/2 = 33cm. Based on the options, B. 30cm is the intended answer.

questions.text: The fundamental frequency of vibration (f) of a wire is measured as a function of the tension (T) in the wire. Which of the following curves adequately represents the data? [Graphs not shown]
questions.explanation: The relationship is f ∝ √T. A graph of f against T would be a square root curve (parabolic). A graph of f against √T would be a straight line through the origin.

questions.text: Which of the diagrams below represents the second overtone of a vibrating string fixed at both ends? [Diagrams not shown]
questions.explanation: For a string fixed at both ends, the second overtone is the third harmonic. It will have four nodes (at the ends and two internal) and three antinodes. The pattern is N-A-N-A-N.

questions.explanation: Pitch is the perceptual correlate of frequency. A higher frequency is perceived as a higher pitch.

questions.text: The physical properties of sound waves can best be described by
questions.explanation: Sound waves are longitudinal waves. Longitudinal waves cannot be polarized. Therefore, any option involving polarization (B, C, D) is incorrect. Sound waves can be reflected (echo) and diffracted (bending around obstacles).

questions.text: In a closed organ pipe producing a musical note, an antinode will always be produced at
options: D. All the parts of the pipe
questions.explanation: In a closed organ pipe, the open end is always a displacement antinode (and a pressure node).

questions.text: In a resonance tube experiment, if the fundamental frequency of the vibrating air column is 280Hz, the frequency of the third overtone is
questions.explanation: For a closed pipe, the fundamental frequency is f₁. The overtones are the odd harmonics: 3f₁, 5f₁, 7f₁... The third overtone is the fourth possible frequency, which is the seventh harmonic: 7 * 280 Hz = 1960 Hz.

questions.text: The lowest note emitted by a stretched string has a frequency of 40Hz. How many overtones are there between 10Hz and 180Hz?
questions.explanation: The fundamental is 40 Hz. The harmonics are: 80 Hz (1st overtone), 120 Hz (2nd overtone), 160 Hz (3rd overtone), 200 Hz (4th overtone). So, between 10 Hz and 180 Hz, we have 80 Hz, 120 Hz, and 160 Hz. That is 3 overtones.

questions.text: The pitch of a sound note depends on
questions.explanation: Pitch is primarily determined by the fundamental frequency of the sound wave. A higher frequency corresponds to a higher pitch.

questions.text: Musical instruments playing the same note can be distinguished from one another owing to the differences in their
questions.explanation: Quality or timbre is the characteristic of sound that enables us to distinguish between different sources, even when they have the same pitch and loudness. It depends on the waveform, which is determined by the number and relative intensities of the overtones present.

questions.text: The characteristic of a vibration that determines its intensity is the
questions.explanation: The intensity (and loudness) of a sound wave is proportional to the square of the amplitude of the vibration.

questions.text: If a sonometer has a fundamental frequency of 450Hz, what is the frequency of the fifth overtone?
questions.explanation: For a string, the fundamental frequency is f₁. The overtones are harmonics: 2f₁, 3f₁, 4f₁, 5f₁, 6f₁... The fifth overtone is the sixth harmonic: 6 * 450 Hz = 2700 Hz.
